JNDI configuration is done via jndi.properties.  Its usually found on 
the CLASSPATH (Read up on JNDI to learn more about configuration).  In 
Heritrix, the default jndi.property file is in the conf subdirectory 
(The default points at a basic Map JNDI implementation, 
http://www.smardec.com/products/jndi.html, included with Heritrix).

The below exception would seem to indicate the jndi.properties can't be 
found or that the MirrorJNDI jar is missing.  Are you using a clean 
checkout of Heritrix source or is your context otherwise?  If the 
latter, make sure that in src/conf and lib/MirrorJNDI.jar are on your 
CLASSPATH.  If the former, I'm unsure whats up.  It works for me (And 
Frank it looks like).

St.Ack


callforshadab wrote:

> at javax.naming.InitialContext.lookup(InitialContext.java:355)

> at org.archive.crawler.Heritrix.getJndiContext(Heritrix.java:2248)
> at org.archive.crawler.Heritrix.registerJndi(Heritrix.java:2225)

> at org.archive.crawler.Heritrix.main(Heritrix.java:471)
>
> Can anybody help me ??

> > Michael Stack wrote:
> > > <snip>
> > > See the tabs. Click on 'Arguments'. There are two places to fill in
> > > arguments. There are application arguments and JVM arguments. I
> > > usually put into the top textbox '--run' so I don't have to go to the
> > > extra step of setting this in the UI. The lower textbox is where you
> > > set '-Dheritrix.development' system property.
> >
> > That worked great- thanks, Stack!
> >
> >
> > > Please try again. I'm not sure I understand what you are asking. Is
> > > there a special modification you've made to the heritrix wrapper
> script
> > > you need to happen when eclipse starts Heritrix? Which files are you
> > > referring to?
> >
> > I was looking for a way to run Heritrix using the heritrix script, but
> > since I am running it in Eclipse, there's no reason.
> >
> > Thanks again,
> > Frank
> >
